STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk2
evidence_span: Nodular corrosion susceptibility of specimens was evaluated by corrosion tests in high-temperature high-pressure steam.

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk2
evidence_span: The test was conducted in a refreshed autoclave by a two-step method proposed by Cheng et al. [13] consisting of a prefilming step at 410°C/10.3 MPa for 8 h and a subsequent nodule sensitization step at 510°C/10.3 MPa for 16 h

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk2
evidence_span: The test was conducted in a refreshed autoclave by a two-step method proposed by Cheng et al. [13] consisting of a prefilming step at 410°C/10.3 MPa for 8 h and a subsequent nodule sensitization step at 510°C/10.3 MPa for 16 h

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk2
evidence_span: Distributions of alloying elements in Zircaloy-2, tin, iron, chromium, and nickel were examined utilizing a computer-aided micro-analyzer (CMA)

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk2
evidence_span: The specimen surface area analyzed in this study was 5 by 5 mm square, which was divided into a 500 by 500 square array of measuring spots of 10 by 10 μm

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk2
evidence_span: measuring spots of 10 by 10 μm

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk2
evidence_span: an average grain diameter of the specimens was 3 to 5 μm

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk2
evidence_span: Only the Lot C specimen was analyzed by a 500 by 500 square array of 5 by 5 μm measuring spots, that is, the totally analyzed area was 2.5 by 2.5 mm

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk2
evidence_span: measuring spots of 5 by 5 μm

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk2
evidence_span: Linear scanning analyses (line analyses) were also made across the analyzing area with a measuring line width of 10 μm, except for the Lot C specimen that was done at 175 μm

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk2
evidence_span: except for the Lot C specimen that was done at 175 μm

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk2
evidence_span: The degree of nodular corrosion varied from the most susceptible specimen, Lot B, fully covered with oxide nodules, to Lot S specimen, being free of nodules

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk2
evidence_span: The corrosion ranking among lots was denoted as heavy nodules for Lots B and C, medium ones for Lot K, small ones for Lot U, and no nodules for Lot S

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk2
evidence_span: Lot C specimen showed a pronounced feature in the appearance of a circumferential discontinuity in nodular corrosion

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk2
evidence_span: Lot CR. prepared from specially heat treated tubeshell, showed no nodules on the outer surface, but had a large number of them on the inner one

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk2
evidence_span: Both the (α+β)- and β-quenched specimens at the final tube size exhibited no nodules on either the outer or inner surfaces

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk2
evidence_span: The distribution profile of alloying element concentrations exhibited a normal distribution for all specimens, excepting Lot B, which showed heavy nodule formation in the corrosion test and had a nearly log-normal distribution

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk2
evidence_span: No significant difference in variances of tin concentrations, which were relatively uniform, was observed among the lots tested

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk2
evidence_span: the respective variances of iron, chromium, and nickel concentrations were larger than that of tin and differed from specimen lot-to-lot

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk2
evidence_span: Among these three elements within a specimen, the variance was the largest for chromium and the smallest for nickel

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk2
evidence_span: A specimen having a larger variance in iron, chromium, and nickel concentrations showed heavier nodular corrosion in high-temperature high-pressure steam

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk4
evidence_span: Most of the added iron, chromium, and nickel is soluble in β-zirconium during the solution treatment process

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk4
evidence_span: precipitates are formed as intermetallics on the subgrain boundaries of the plate structure of α zirconium by cooling down to the α-phase

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk4
evidence_span: The sizes of both the precipitates and α-platelets vary according to the cooling rate

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk4
evidence_span: A lower cooling rate causes coarser ones

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk4
evidence_span: Among the three elements, variance is largest for chromium and smallest for nickel

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk4
evidence_span: Major precipitates in Zircaloy-2 are Zr(Fe,Cr)₃ and Zr₂(Fe,Ni)

evidence_span: A region of heavy nodules contains smaller area-averaged amounts of all elements

evidence_span: an opposite effect of tin has been reported

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk4
evidence_span: Nodular corrosion susceptibility of a specimen changes from heavy nodule formation to no nodules with (α+β) or β-quenching

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk4
evidence_span: Both (α+β) and β-quenching tend to homogenize the concentrations of iron, chromium, and nickel

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk4
evidence_span: Local deficiencies in iron, chromium, and nickel are substantially eliminated by this effect

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk4
evidence_span: these treatments improve nodular corrosion resistance

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk4
evidence_span: No significant changes in alloying element distribution are caused even after the subsequent cold rolling and α-annealing processes

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk4

evidence_span: Heavier nodules appeared on a specimen with larger variance

evidence_span: A local area, deficient in iron, chromium, and nickel, was proposed as one site for nodule nucleation

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk4
evidence_span: Both (α+β) and β-quenching could substantially eliminate the local deficiencies in iron, chromium, and nickel by homogenizing these elements

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk4
evidence_span: Hence these treatments improved nodular corrosion resistance

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk4

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk5
evidence_span: Electron microscope techniques were used to investigate black and white oxide films, formed before and after the oxidation transition, on Zircaloy-2 in superheated steam at 673 and 773 K

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk5
evidence_span: A compressive stress gradient distributed through the thickness of black oxide films was measured to be ~500 MPa/μm in films with a thickness of 1.2 μm

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk5
evidence_span: decreasing to ~60 MPa/μm with an increase in film thickness to 2.1 μm when nodular corrosion appears

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk5
evidence_span: Monoclinic, cubic, and tetragonal lattice structures in black oxide films formed both at 673 and 773 K have been identified

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk5
evidence_span: The proportion of cubic and tetragonal phases decreases with the increase of temperature and turns into an exclusively monoclinic lattice structure in white oxide films after oxidation transition

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk5
evidence_span: The grain size in black oxide films is extremely fine (<50 nm)

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk5
evidence_span: It was observed from a high resolution lattice image that the oxide crystals consist of mosaics ~20 nm in size

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk5
evidence_span: Pores (<10 nm) existing on triple grain boundaries in the white oxide films have been observed

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_024_chunk5
evidence_span: Small areas in black oxide films, which are 3 to 4 times more than the average thickness, are considered to be the nuclei of nodular corrosion
